newsitem.title: LEBANON: Lebanese warlord suffering "slow death" - lawyers.
newsitem.headline: Lebanese warlord suffering "slow death" - lawyers.

text.p: Lawyers for Lebanon's jailed former Christian warlord Samir Geagea complained that his prolonged solitary confinement in an underground defence ministry cell is subjecting him to "a process of slow death".

"Dr Geagea's state of health arouses concern," lawyers said in a communique published in Beirut newspapers on Saturday demanding that authorities treat him in accordance with the Lebanese constitution and international humanitarian norms.
Geagea, 44, who led the Lebanese Forces Christian militia in the 1975-90 civil war, has been in solitary confinement since his arrest in April 1994.
He has been convicted of two murders and is serving two life sentences.
"We cannot believe that the desire to take revenge against him, his sympathisers and those who share his convictions, or even those related to him, can reach such animosity," the lawyers said.
"He has become slim, pale coloured, and his eyes are deeply set after being detained since nearly three years in a narrow underground cell, where fresh air and sunshines can not reach," they added.
"He breathes fresh air only one hour daily, and he is not allowed to any radio, television, newspaper or magazine. such conditions violate the Lebanese constitution," the lawyers added.
